name: Moderator Bill
comment info:
Greetings everyone!  

I am Moderator Bill, a high school math teacher in Collinsville, IL.  I will be taking over moderating duties from the fantastic Moderator Sharon.  

I wanted to share my thoughts with this graph as I start reviewing and responding to other's comments.  

The obvious thing to notice is that specific science and technology jobs are projected to have larger projected positive job growths over the next 10 years while service industry jobs are projected to have a negative growth over the same time period.  These projected changes are what they say they are: projected, meaning it is not a guaranteed thing to occur, but, based on mathematical models using current data, could possibly happen, especially in using this "strong-impact scenario".   We should always consider key words in reports, like in this story: "How MIGHT....", to realize that, again, these are just projected numbers.  Things can easily change for the better or for the worse over the next ten years.

I believe this information gives students still in school some insight into potential areas of future studies if they want to have more job security later in life.  The article that includes this graph mentions that 75% of all employment sectors are projected to change by less than 2%, so the jobs we see here only represent a small portion of the largest projected changes.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s bar chart shows the largest projected percentage changes, both negatively and positively, in the number of jobs by employment sector for the period from 2019 to 2029.  This change is due, in part, to the effects of the pandemic on the U.S. economy’s long-term, job trends.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Britlyanne Remfort --

You “wonder is how accurate this graph.  This is a 10-year projection.  Projections are always risky since so much can happen to the job market over this long period.  But, projections are necessary for planning.  As with this one, they can be revised.  (Here, this projection in February 2021 was a revision on the September 2020 projection.)  What you may want to do is look at the BLS report that was the source of the data.  The title of the February 2021 report is “Employment Projections in a Pandemic Environment.”

replies.comment info:
HI, @Ian Rios --

You mention entertainment.  Which sectors listed here have to do with entertainment?  The article that includes this graph mentions that 75% of all employment sectors are projected to change by less than 2%.  Entertainment jobs may be in this 75%.

Consider the number of employees by sector.  Some sectors have more jobs than others.  Now, combine this with the percentage changes.  Though there is projected to be a 24.2% decline in restaurant jobs, there are a lot of jobs in this sector and, over the coming decade, about ¾ will remain.  What should a student do it the student is interested in a restaurant job?

name: Joseph Mendoza
comment info: I notice that this is a graph regarding how future jobs might be impacted as a result of the current Coronavirus pandemic. I can see that the highest increase is in epidemiology, which makes sense because we are in a pandemic. The increased jobs that come after it are also in the medical field, biochemistry, and data analyzers, and biomedical technicians. I can see that what might decrease over time are jobs in retail, restaurants, and other in-person jobs. I wonder as to why it is that we see this trend. My assumptions are that the current pandemic really took a toll on how we are living now -- it has become the norm that people stay at home and work in addition to students learning from home as well. This narrative defeats the purpose of having office buildings and schools because what was once done in person can be also done at home. This reasoning might be the reason why we see these trends. The impact that this has on me and my community is that it makes it a lot harder to look towards a positive and pre-covid future because of how long we've been in a pandemic. I feel like in my community we might start seeing less people working in offices when the same jobs can be done at home. Maybe in schools, a lot of programs will be done online to eliminate the struggle of finding buildings and providing necessities. Catchy headline: "What Jobs Might Look Like Post-Pandemic".

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Joseph Mendoza --

You mention several times that people will work less in offices after the pandemic.  Why is this?  What jobs will decline because more people are working at home?  Which jobs will increase because more people are working at home?

name: Ellie
comment info:
I noticed that jobs related to STEM have surged in the strong impact scenario while jobs in the service sector have greatly fallen. The general trend appears to follow the COVID health guidelines. For example, the CDC doesn't recommend travel for recreation right now, which explains why the reservation and transportation ticket agents and travel checks industry has negative job loss instead of growth. I wonder how dependant this perspective data is on COVID restrictions. For instance, if the future is not reflective of a strong impact scenario, will cashiers still have a similar percent of job loss caused by something else, like businesses preferring technology (self-checkouts) because of preferable costs? This will impact the composition of jobs among industries that make up the job market in totality. For example, if there are fewer available employment opportunities for bartenders those individuals will have to find a job in another industry. This could have an interesting impact on educational attainment levels. Individuals who were bartenders but are now unemployed may choose to go to school to become web developers or database administrators. This could have an interesting secondary impact on political demographics, as education level is a primary indicator of voting behavior. 
Catchy Headline: "Back to the Future: will the job market ever recover?"
